arm_group.description: Assessment of intubation conditions after onset of the neuromuscular block at the m. trapezius
assessment of intubation conditions after onset of the neuromuscular block at the m. adductor pollicis

brief_summary.textblock:
Accelerometric Assessment of neuromuscular block during anaesthesia is routinely performed
      at the M. adductor pollicis. However, many operations require positioning of the patients
      with arms attached to the body. In these situations, the anaesthesiologist has no access to
      the m.adductor pollicis.

      In this study, a new position of accelerometry at the neck is evaluated: Stimulation of the
      n. accessorius with accelerometry of the m. trapezius.

clinical_study.brief_title: Accelerometry at the Neck: Comparison With m. Adductor Pollicis Stimulation
clinical_study.condition: Feasibility of Measurement of a Neuromuscular Block at the m. Trapezius

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients undergoing general anaesthesia with endotracheal intubation

          -  weight 50-90 kg

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Pregnancy

          -  allergy to one of the drugs used

          -  risk of pulmonary aspiration

          -  expected difficulties with endotracheal intubation

          -  intake of drugs known to influence neuromuscular block

          -  infection (CRP > 0,5 mg/dl, leukocyte count > 12000/µl)

intervention.intervention_name: accelerometry m. trapezius and m. adductor pollicis

primary_outcome.description: Comparison between time to recovery [s] to a train of four ratio of 0.9 between both groups
primary_outcome.measure: Recovery to a train of  four ratio of 0.9

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of onset time [s] between both groups. Onset time is defined as decrease of T1 to < 5% of initial twitch height.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label
